::: {.question-block}
<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module3_mcq_q13')" data-correct-answer="D">
<strong style="display: block;">
An investor applies the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) to evaluate a stock. 
The stock has a beta of 1.5, the risk-free rate is 4%, and the expected market return is 10%. 
According to CAPM, what is the expected return on this stock, and how does it reflect the risk–return tradeoff?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q13" value="A"> A. 10% — equal to the market return, implying no compensation for additional risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q13" value="B"> B. 11% — slightly above the market, underestimating the effect of beta.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q13" value="C"> C. 12% — consistent with a moderate level of risk above the market.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q13" value="D"> D. 13% — equal to 4% + 1.5 × (10% − 4%), reflecting the higher expected return required for above-average systematic risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module3_mcq_q13" value="E"> E. 15% — overstated relative to CAPM, exaggerating the risk premium.</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module3_mcq_q13" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: D. CAPM gives E(R) = 4% + 1.5 × (10% − 4%) = 13%. The higher beta implies the stock is riskier than the market, so investors require a higher expected return as compensation for bearing additional systematic risk.
</div>
:::
